millsfield:images_texts:
Wind velocity, gustiness and turbulence.
Considering the entire period of observation, the greatest
average wind velocity occurred at Site No. 2, with Site No. 5,
Sites Nos. 1, 4 and 6 and Site No. 5 following in order.
The
prevailing winds blew with greater average velocity at both
Site No. 2 and Site No. 5 than at Sites Nos. 1, 4 and 6, but ex-
treme velocities of 30, 35 and 40 miles per hour or more were
recorded a greater number of times at Sites Nos. 1, 4 and 6 than
at Site No. 5. Everything considered, Site No. 5 is as windy as
Sites Nos. 1, 4 and 6 and Site No. 2 is even more so. The least
average wind velocity and the greatest freedon from high winds
were found at Site No. 3.
Although the lightest average winds and greatest freedom
from high wind velocities were found at Site No. 3, the winds
there were very gusty, decidedly more so than at any of the other
suggested sites. Gustiness was greater at Site No. 2 than at any
of the others with the exception of Site No. 3 and there was little
difference between Sites Nos. 1, 4 and 6 and Site No. 5, the latter
having a slight advantage.
Investigation of turbulence in the first 1000 feet above the
ground revealed practically identical conditions at Site No. 3
and Site No. 6, and less favorable conditions over the other
proposed locations.
Precipitation and Temperature.
Precipitation, the one remaining meteorological element
for which comparative data were obtained, did not vary between

the several proposed sites by any considerable amount. Neither
the precipitation data in Table 19 nor the temperature data in
Table 20 have any important bearing on airport location within
the area under consideration but they will be found to have
other practical applications.
Conditions Summarized.
From the consideration of data that have been presented,
it is obvious that Site No. 6 (Mills Field)* has an advantage
over all other proposed sites in freedom from fog, visability, ceil-
ing, and constancy of wind direction.
Moreover, the prevailing
wind direction at Site No. 6 (Mills Field*) is such that the majority
of take-offs may be made over favorable territory, which cannot be
said for any other proposed site, excepting No. 4 (adjoining and to
the south of Mills Field*). In fact, departures may be made in any
direction from Site No. 6 (M111s Field*) with favorable conditions
for an emergency landing in the proximity of the airport should
occasion require it.
It was also found that the variation in wind direction from
moment to moment at Site No. 6 (Mills Field*) was less than at any
other proposed site except No. 2 (South San Francisco*). The surface
wind velocity at Site No. 6 (Mills Field) was found to be more
(South s.F.*)
advantageous for the operation of aircraft than at Site No. 2/and
equally with Site No. 5 (Pt. San Mateo*), although smaller average
wind velocities and greater freedom from high winds occurred at
Site No. 3 (Beresford*). The latter site, however, has a distinct
disadvantage on account of excessive gustiness, an evil from
which x& Site No. 6 (Mills Field) is relatively free.
No other pro-
posed site had less turbulence in the lower levels of the air than
Site No. 6 (Mills Piela)* while, above 1000 feet, smather air was
NOTE: *Words in parenthesis do not occur in text.

indicated over Site No. 6 (1111s Field*) than over any of the others.
Site Recommended.
Site No. 6 (Mills Field) the location of the present temporary
airport, is therefore recommended as a result of the meteorological
survey as the most suitable one for the permanent location of
the San Francisco Municipal Airport. All factors considered,
no other suggested site appears to have as favorable meteorological
conditions as this one.
The present site of the San Franci sco Municipal Airport
includes a small portion of Site No. 4 (adjoining and to the south
of Mills Field*), and, should it become advisable to extend the
boundaries of the present airport in a north-south direction, the
survey shows that the extension should be to the southward.
Meteorological conditions over Site No. 2 (South San Francisco*)
preclude extension in that direction as they indicate more fog,
lower ceilings, poorer visability, higher wind velocities and more
turbulence than are found over the present site of the airport and
the area immediately south thereor.
NOTE:
*Words in parenthesis do not occur in text.
